result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) and Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs) was dismissed by the court.

  • Christopher S Worzalla was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Christopher S Worzalla was found guilty of Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 343.44(1)(b).
  • Christopher S Worzalla was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Do not possess or consume alcohol (absolute sobriety) or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.  
Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent.

Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in custody. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Cases 15CF391 and 15TR2802 are heard today.
  Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement. 15CF391 ct 1: I/S Prison 30 in & 30 es sentence-stay and to be on Probation for 36 mo w/conditions. Ct 2: fine/costs 5 days time served jail, Ct 4: I/S 180 days jail-stay, pay costs and surcharges.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
15CF391 Ct 1: OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs): No Contest
15CF391 Ct 2: OAR: No Contest
15CF391 Ct 4: Resist: No Contest

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty 15CF391 cts 1, 2, & 4.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date. 15CF391 Ct 3 is dismissed and read in and Ct 5 is dismissed. 15TR2802 is dismissed and read in.

ADA Cousins makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Barkley concurs with joint recommendation. 
Defendant makes statements to the Court.

BY THE COURT:*****PROBATION**
15CF391 Ct 1: OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs):
I/S Sentence: 30 months Incarceration and 30 months Extended Supervision - stayed
Probation: 36 months
Conditions:
187 days jail - 187 days credit (time served)
$600 fine + costs = $1,569.00
36 months Revocation of DL
36 months IID
DOT Assess/Safety plan
AODA & comply with treatment recommendations.  
Do not possess or consume alcohol (absolute sobriety) or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.  
Maintain full time employement
Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent.

15CF391 Ct 2: OAR: $150 fine + costs = $442.00
5 days jail - time served

15CF391 Ct 4: Resist: 
I/S Sentence: 180 days jail - stayed
Probation 12 months
Conditions:
Comply with conditions as stated in Count 1. 
Pay costs.

Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in custody. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Corrections Officer Borski is also present.
Cases heard are 15CF-391 and 15TR-2802.

10:05 AM Court calls case.
Court states appearances.

Atty Barkley addresses the Court, this is a motion to modify bond. Cash portion is not being requested, but for Defendant to participate in new program, Portage County Pretrial Home Detention Program.  An evaluation was done. Atty Barkley presents a copy of the evaluation to the Court. State has received their copy of the evaluation.

Atty Barkley addresses the Court with regards to the conditions of this detention program.

Court questions Officer Borski.

Atty Barkley continues addresses the Court regarding the evaluation form.

Atty Cousins addresses the Court, objects for reasons stated on the record.

Atty Barkly addresses the Court, states that his client can afford the cost of the program.

Court questions Atty Barkley regarding Defendant's employment and drivers license.

BY THE COURT:
Court will grant the motion but impose conditions in addition.

State believes the motion granted is sufficient, there is no paper order.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for February 1, 2016 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Christopher S Worzalla in custody. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
3:01 p.m.  Court calls the case. 

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for November 30, 2015 at 08:30 am.
Granted, Petitioner shall be responsible for reimbursing the county for 50% of atty fees on conclusion of the case.
